comments.commentBody: As a franchised dealer I can see both sides of the argument In today's world, the Internet has made the availability of information very easy, it is a very competitive environment and the margins are shrinking year over year, in a lot of instances; a new car dealer takes a loss when selling new cars, the income produced by arranging financing is an income source dealers use to supplement the very small margin and therefor it is a necessity. Consumers have all of the info they need to make an educated buying decision, invoice prices on new cars and fair market value on used cars are easily accessible on sites like nada.com or kbb.com etc. In many instances dealers are not even allowed to mark up subprime loans, and on the good credit customers dealers are paid a flat fee for arranging the financing and doing the paperwork instead of the bank. Marking up interest rates is almost a practice of the past, many dealers with myself included prefer to be paid a flat fee because marking up the rate subjects the dealer to the possibility of chargeback by he lender for unearned income due to a customer paying off the loan early which is almost inevitable since most people trade in their vehicles every 3 to 4 years! So marking up the rate is not real income until the customer makes all of their scheduled payments.To sum up, do your research and have multiple options, dealers actually appreciate a consumer that knows what they want and one that have done their research.

Nocera, if you know the history of the ACA, you have to take into account its fate in the court system and the overwhelming opposition from its opponents. We are talking folks who were willing to shut down the US government on account of a healthcare law.

This law was written to set up state exchanges for health insurance. Indeed states that have their own exchanges are not experiencing nearly as much headache as healthcare.gov is. Kentucky, California, Colorado have reported success. For states that have no exchanges, the Feds recruited navigators to help with the sign up. But those navigators have been fought and practically run out of states like Florida. In addition, states are taking longer to let the Feds know whether or not they will (a) accept Medicare expansion, and (b) set up exchanges. Those decisions have an overall bearing on the capacity of the website, I should think.

But hey, Bay of Pigs, Katrina, Iraq war, are all the compositions made so far to the ACA. I think NYMag had it right when they run a story imagining how Gettysburg would have been covered by current media, to wit: is Gettysburg Lincoln's Katrina?
You're absolutely correct. It's totally ridiculous, on every level and every way.

Commenters who are certain the peanut allergy should be accommodated at all times are overlooking the reality that other passengers may have health issues of their own.

I have a severely (read: airborne) peanut-allergic friend whose safety is important to me. I also have hypoglycemic episodes, under some circumstances, if I fail to eat protein for as short a time as three hours. I live in a body that's not great at handling lactose and unable to digest soy. On days we've spent multiple hours together, I have worked hard to figure out how to accommodate my needs without endangering my friend with peanut-based snacks. That calculus can be difficult and nervewracking even for someone very motivated to get it right.

People who think the airline is being sensible are not necessarily bogeymen. They may just have looked at the situation -- someone's kid could die if they've failed to wash their hands or clothes after a meal -- and been horrified that they might kill someone due to a mistake that's easy to make when they're rushing to catch a flight.

Martin, I'll have you know, sir, that there our still pockets galore all across this great land that simply adora Zadora!

No PIA'S, No Justice!"

Howie TBOQ
On the other hand, apart from visiting his tanning salon the Speaker hasn't much else to occupy his time.

Leapy,

Hang time is mostly an optical illusion. And being able to jump real high.
http://www.sciencekids.co.nz/videos/sports/hangtime.html

@Stu

That's how his bosses at Heritage like it.

Will address the XWP in a separate C-in-C. Wanted to cap off a topic of recent discussion:

Many of you related stories of recollecting the JFK murder; RiA went beyond with his fine meditation on the man rather than the demise. All of you, I think, would find this piece enlightening: http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/11/22/a-50-year-timesman-reca... ; perhaps go back and read RiA's reminiscence before or after reading that Times piece.

I realize I have recommended the blogger of that piece more times than I can count, but I don't think anyone will disagree with me on the quality of the writing in this particular blog post.

Besides, Deb is on record saying the blogger is an excellent public editor.

The blogger posted that item around the start of the business day on The Anniversary (she controls the timing of her own blog posts, and sometimes gets strategic). I on the other hand waited until after The Anniversary was over to say the following, because The Anniversary seemed important to so many among you:

On that day, Nov. 22, 1963 -- the day that Elke swore allegiance to the Maple Leaf (and probably to Her Majesty) -- the world lost Clive Staples Lewis. Though often represented in crosswords with ASLAN or NARNIA, he was much more than that. I was hoping to see this SAT XWP dedicated to the old Irishman C.S. but I will be satisfied to have mentioned him here.

Thanks.
My last sentence should read "Obamacare is the least of them."
Yes!
AND what is really remarkable - how this thought experiment of (once?) every single conscious liberal has been totally forgotten in the US.

If you wanted to design an economic system to inflict maximum damage on the miracle that is our planet and the life it nurtures you would devise one based on perpetual growth dependent on materialism and wanton consumerism sustained by obscene amounts of debt and propagate it globally.
The world desperately needs a wholesome leader to stand up and wholeheartedly denounce the prevailing economic decadence that is not only destroying the planet but the moral fibre of civilisation.
That we deify the economy and desecrate the planet belies our claim to be intelligent life.

We're adding millions more to single payer (in addition to Medicare, there's now the new Medicaid beneficiaries). I actually think that single payer will be brought about in a few years because insurance companies will mostly throw in the towel. Those that are left will become non-profit.

Basically, a single payer system.

CJGC, I agree with your comment about technology roll-outs. Those saying that the healthcare.gov is so bungled are often the same ones saying Medicare for all. But those calling for it never explain how to deal with the symbiosis between the insurance industry and the medical community which encompasses the lives of millions people, thousands of companies and hundreds of billions of dollars. If one feels the ACA implementation is complex and meets with opposition, do tell how single payer goes smoothly?

Almost never does the general public get to observe and experience the rollout of a very complex computer system. So we really have no way to judge. That, of course, doesn't stop the Republicans who want nothing more than for the ACA as a whole, and the president in particular, to fail. So many naysayers. The rollout of the Massachusetts plan wasn't smooth either but nothing much was made of it and it did get fixed and works fine.

Further, as far as I can tell, the states that have Medicaid programs are experiencing many fewer problems. Unless a state by state analysis shows different, I think we can assume that where there's cooperation at the state level there are many fewer problems than in the states where the governors and the legislature are gunning for Obama. They don't seem to care much about their own citizens.

Too bad that single-payer was dismissed out of hand by both parties at the start.

The party who has a "bad name" is the GOP that gives the black president 82 filibusters while the last 42 presidents only had 86 filibusters combine.

The party who has a bad name is the GOP who took the country to war with Iraq base on faulty WMD, and who forgot to put the cost in their accountant book until the black president came to office.

This website bug will fix, however, GOP's bug will remain until they're totally lose the house in 2014 and the presidency in 2016.

Linda, do not ignore the role of private enterprise in all of this. It is comfortable for all of us to hide under our ideological blankets. This story relates failure by both government and private businesses.

To those of you who are interpreting my comment as pro GOP, read it again!!! Whether or not you like Obamacare, this was a big $$$ price tag on the rollout and should have been put in the hands of the right people.

However, when someone tells you it's not working, don't put your agenda over common sense. This was a big PR disaster for Obama. Not because of Obamacare, but because of the rollout price tag it is costing us/ Had it been in the hands of those with both health care and tech knowledge, I think it would have been a successful rollout.

One can still be a moderate Democrat and speak out!!! It's only the Liberals and Conservatives who put a positive spin on bad policy decisions because ideology trumps common sense!!!!....and I am not referring to Obamacare.

RTTT is the worst ed program to hit the USA since NCLB!!!
This is what gives government spending a bad name.   That and hubris.

@Bill Des Moines

"The Pentagon's Joint Strike Fighter has been under development for at least two decades, and cost upwards of one-trillion dollars. It has been plagued with problems. And it won't be ready for front line combat service for years."
Is this a waste?
LOL  Your government in action. Then again, less than a Billion wasted so who cares.
I remember it as the anteater, too, from when I read B.C. as a kid.  It was the sound his long skinny tongue made when it darted out.

Fascinating, Leapy. Many Jewish and/or Canadian poets are being cited in this thread!

Speaking of poets, as you did re Leonard Cohen: Lou Reed's career was heavily influenced by one (Delmore Schwartz, at the elite Syracuse University) as well; then later Patti Smith. Having said that, I can see other similarities between he and L. Cohen, which I won't go O.T. with.

An email from my cousin who blogs about music informs me that his son's good friend goes to Lou Reed's old HS. School has a photo up of Reed, who was on the track team in addition to being a paid musician. By all accounts, he was happy on LI and in HS; he even moved back in with his parents for a bit after a couple of velvety underground years.

It is altogether fitting that I mentioned Canadians in my C-I-C, because Fred Healy is from your home and naturalized land (see 11D, "BC").

Perhaps his British Columbianality will evoke comment from Robert and Elke (who, it just occurred to me, are lucky to perhaps fit comfortably in some of the better known low-slung FAST CARs?).

Mash-up of the BC comic and CS Lewis would get us to the BCS, hated by college-football fans. Oh, is there a game today in New Haven?

Wanted to expand a bit about CS Lewis: His late-life love, Joy, was the 2nd of his 2 known long-term alliances. The title of "Surprised by Joy" refers not only to the fact that she arrived in his life unexpectedly but also to the fact that his Christian perspectives let him remain joyful after her death.
The last time the word was in a NYT puzzle I think it was spelled BOOTIES, and I wondered at the time why it wasn't still the BOOTEES I always remembered.  That made me hesitate this time.

I agree with those who called it a strangely quick SAT XWP. I however extended it to my normal SAT range by spending over 7 minutes figuring out where my one error was.

For some reason, I had EXTaNTS instead of EXTENTS. PENTa made perfect sense, but "EXTaNTS"? I wasted a lot of time playing around with letters in 11D, which I need explained; also wondered why BOOTEES is spelled that way.

Thought I was going to fly through this because right at 1,2, and 3 I was a JETS FAN who has read ULALUME and landed in JAKARTA! (Although I did not change planes, the flight number changed, as well as the smoking rules; in every row of the plane, an Indonesian LITA cig!)

A few other ITEMS were in my wheelhouse; I know that many musicians in the JAZZ AGE were wont to SHOOT UP, and that Mario LANZA's success came AT A COST. I knew the explorer but it RANKLES that AMERIGO gets primacy: earlier explorers sailed into UNMAPPED waters!

The FIBBER clue was a NEAT IDEA! I ACED HANG TIME and did not punt for DEPTH. I am reminded that I should have discussed Lou Reed's A PLUS version of "CEZANNE" (not to be confused with "Suzanne" by Jewish Montrealer Leonard Cohen). Speaking of Canada, pecantart's travels came to mind: Would she prefer her muscle-toning PASEOS, or a muscly FAST CAR, I wondered. Remembered to mention C.S. Lewis because he expressed ALARM at finding late-life love ("Surprised by Joy").

And just to clarify: Unlike fellow LI-er Billy Joel, I do not have a tab at ZANZIBAR!

It's a good question, but is it really a hard one?  What makes a good pianist a good pianist, a good dancer a good dancer?  Is it only because of a handful of highly publicized productions happen to appear in NYC around the same time?  A feature like this is unlikely to appear in paper in London, Ashland, Spring Green or Toronto.  The answer is experienced study of the playwright and his way of writing, voice, diction, great acting, a powerful imagination and theatrical craft.  The question really ought to be: what makes a so-called theater town (and its critics) so provincial?

Blanchard changed the convention on the exchange rate in his excellent macro textbook ; he defines it as the price of the dollar in units of foreign exchange. He upset me because now I have to deal with two different conventions. I am not an economist, just a concerned citizen who wants to know what's going on.

Thanks for pointing me to photos of Flat Coats, Five. They have delightful faces, although the one photo I saw of a soaking wet Smoothie looked like Frank Zappa.

Oddly, Wikipedia has a photo of one that isn't black. Beautiful coloring though.

It's impossible to tell size in these close-up photos. How EXTENTSive an animal is Soupy? Also wondered about his DEPTH of personality, how much he PANTS, and whether he is VISE or instead SLOW ON THE UPTAKE. You have mentioned that he only completes half of a fetch; another good test is how quickly he learned to shake HANS.

I remember he got his own cheeseburger on the drive to your currently-named city; I just can't remember if you SAIS he puts SALT ON his French Fries?

I hope you and WHH took note that I -- rather than TAKE AIM at the first dozen words of your comment -- avoided all such TABUS?

Kol b'SEDER.
Scientists invent technical terms, terms of art, to think precisely and clearly about a subject. Otherwise, it's very difficult or impossible to analyze a complex problem.

Got it. The stat of hangtime is the total time spent in the air, not the time spent 'hovering' [as I had thought]. I had suspected the appearance of hovering might come from drawing up the legs, but apparently it comes from stretching up the upper body.

Cool video.

With J.P. Morgan Chase forking over a $13 billion payout to federal regulators it would take a degree of unbelievable insouciance for other bankers caught up in the subprime mortgage mess not to be shaking in their shoes. Forgive my cynicism, but I entertain no hopes that the prospect of fines and penalties, no matter how large, will change the bankers' behavior. No one I ever heard of goes to work for one of these outfits expecting to get caught.

Quite the contrary, a principal reason why people go to business school is to learn how not to get caught. For the past twenty years the entire investment banking culture has been about refining the art of doing business through smoke and mirrors, and getting very well paid for it. Ten years ago, anyone, and I do mean anyone, who paid the slightest bit of attention to what these banks were doing could predict that they would do exactly what has gotten them into trouble now. We see the results.

What's missing from J.P. Morgan Chase's settlement with the government is a requirement that the people responsible for the bank's wrongdoing be fired, and that they forfeit all benefits. That includes their current CEO and Chairman of the Board. These people, and those employed by other financial institutions who are guilty of the same sort of conduct should be made unemployable within the banking industry.

Apart from that, sensible regulation to curb major abuses, strictly enforced, would seem to be the only reasonable way to go.

I think car dealers were exempted from Dodd-Frank at the outset.

Since then, the so-called implementation process, which I call "limplementation" has been one of serially exempting everyone until nothing will be left.
The roll-out of any major bill is accompanied by complaints , mistakes, and so forth but not many are also accompanied by  active sabotage, insurgency, and a nasty rhetorical campaign

Dr. K,

For some reason I felt that these lyrics were directed at me and my passion for superconducting Maglev technology. However, the lyrics that stuck were "bit by bit". Bit by bit the world will realize that all-electric, quiet, efficient, and fast transport is the path to our future.

Using the repelling force of Superconducting Magnets to transport goods, autos and people is inevitable. Wheels are not obsolete but their use will be limited. The freedom and infinite departure times, and range of the fueled automobile will never be discarded.

That is why our next writing project will be to describe a system for using carbon dioxide to make diesel fuel by using electricity beamed from Maglev launched solar generating stations in space orbit beaming electric power to receiving stations on Earth.

This same capability will also bit by bit create a capability to deflect asteroids on a course that would destroy most living creatures on Earth, maybe even homo sapiens. Bit by bit this capability will be realized.

The A.C.A. will also fitbit by fitbit harmonize our knowledge of personal physiology with the norms of our species and bring better health to all without visits to the medical industrial complex. Imagine a "bodybook" network for our endocrine system. What a super future that will be.

The author might have dwelt a bit more on the fact that the French occupation of Mexico City, to force a republican government into exile and install Emperor Maximilian, occurred before Gettysburg.   In retrospect, it must have been the case that President Lincoln, when preparing his Gettysburg Address, was deeply concerned by that occupation, and that the phrase 'government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the Earth' reflects, in part, that concern.
